South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

PALESTINE - SYRIA MAIL SERVICE-The fast steamers Assouan, Minieh and Menzaleh leave Alexandria alter- nately on Saturdays at 4 p.m. for Jaffa (for Jerusalem), Caifta (for Nazareth), Beyrouth (for Damascus), Tripoli, Alexandretta, and Mersina calling fortnightly at Larnaca (Cyprus) and ctoninuing from Beyrout in alternate weeks to Rhodes, Smyrna, Mitylene, Dardanelles, Gallipoli and Constantinople.

SUDAN - DIRECT MAIL SERVICE.-The mail steamers Dakahlieh and Kosseir leave Suez alternately on Wednes- days at 5 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakim in connection with the Sudan Government Railways express service to Khartoum.
RED SEA COASTING MAIL SERVICE.-Mail steamers leave Suez on Mondays at 5 p.m. for Tor (for Sinai Yambo and Jeddah, continuing in alternate weeks to Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeidah and Aden

div.head: AERIAL WARFARE POSSIBILITIES
div.p: France, which boilt the first ironclad and led the w*y in the cycle trade and the motorcar industry, is also ahead in "conquest of tha air;" though "paced" apparently by America. Already people other than pessimistic poet* begin to see visions of "aerial navies battling in the oentral blue." On the occasion of the great military review in Paris last week, the cigar shaped airship "La Patrie'' successfully executed a scries of manœuvres in mid-air. Further testimony of the dirigible qualities of the "Patrie" was afforded on July 22, when the Premier, M. Clemenoeau, and the Minister for War, General Pioquart, made an ascent and manoeuvred about over the city of Paris for several hours. In a subsequent interview M. Clemenceau said that he waa vary favourably impressed by the wonderful sense of stability he experienced during the trip. "One could not have felt more safe on the deck of a greet liner," he said. "We descended, and so gently did the marvellous machine alight that we did not know we had touched earth again until ae were told so." According to tho Paris correspondent of the "Daily Chronicle/ several new dirigibles on the model of the "Patrie" are being constructed forthwith, and M. Joiliot, the engineer of Messrs. Lebaudy Brass., and designer of the "Patrie," counts upon introducing many improvements in the new airebip. A sum of £19,000 now remains on the estimates for the building of the new ship, bat the military commission's to ask Parliament for a fresh credit. Although the "Lebaudy"was purchased for £4,000, the "Patrie" cost £14,000, and this is to be the sum paid lor the additional ships. M. Julliot is certain ébat the "Petrie'' and airships of her class will play an important part in the land war of the future. They would, he points out, be of inestimable value to the commander of a besieged garrison. It is next to impossible for artillery to hit a spherical- uliaped mass fifty metres long travelling at forty kilometres an honr at an altitude of 10 0 metres. A story of how Germany has been trying to discover the secret of the oonstruotiou of the "Patrie" is published in the "Petit Parisien" and quoted in the "Times." A company was founded last year in Germany for the study of aerial navigation. Its manager, Herr von KeJiler, jonrneyed to Paris in September last to ask M. Julliot if ba oould construct 'Tor sporting purposes" a steerable balloon, like the one madeby him for MM. Lebaudy. He offered 1,001,000 marks (£60,000). M. Julliot induced Herr von Kehler to write to MM. Lebaudy, who replied on the morrow : "We have to inform yon that we oannot, to our great regret, construct the steerable balloon that you desire." Tho rebuff was what was to be expected, but Germany did not abandon the hope of securing the balloon by purchase, as oertaiu facts which may ultimately become known will prove. But, meanwhile, she is trying to copy the French war balloon from such data as are already common property. Whether site will suooed is another matter, for while the general principles of construction are well known, the deiioate calculations concerning essential relations between parts of the machine remain M. Julliot's secret If France, therefore, resolutely continues to oonstruct a fleet of airehipa on his model it will be difficult for any Power, even suppoaiug the right formula be found, to oatch up with her. For as was indicated in the Paris correspondence of the 'Timaa/ the training of the crews is, perhaps, more than half the problem. The cigar shaped war bpllon with which the German authorities arc experimenting made a successful aecwnt oo July 23 from the depdt in Jungfcrobesde, between Chariot- teoborg, and Spaodan. During a cruise of over three hours it appeared readily to answer the helm.

div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and 0.) will be diatributed at the Alexandria Post Office at half peat four this afternoon.

div.p: As we go to press we are informed by tele- phone that a big tire in raging in aome stores at Uabbari, but owing to the late hour at which we receive the news no details are available.

div.head: Libel Case
div.p: Mr. Cuuienoe, proprietor of the newspaper "Le Bpepùre," ha* been condemmed by the Hellenic Consular Tribunal to six months' f imprisonment and a fine of [2,000 francs for libel against 'Mr. Tambacopoulo.

div.head: Cairo Drinking Water
div.p: Dr. Hussein Bff. Yousri, of Cairo lias sent cards of invitation to bis confrères calling them to à meeting at his house on Friday 9th inst to discuss tlio properties of the drinking water of the Artesian Wells.

div.head: Police Budget
div.p: During the last 24 hours, 9 thefts, 9 misdemeanours and 41 contraventions were reported in Cairo and its suburbs against 4 thefts, 14 misdemeanours and 51 oontra- o vendons recorded during the preceding 24 hours.

div.head: Cutting thr Khalig
div.p: The official ceremony of cutting the Kha- lig will take place at Ppum el-Khalig, Old Cairo, on the evening of the 24th instant, o with the customary formalities and fêta All Government offices will be closed on the 25th instant

div.head: Quarantine Board
div.p: The monthly meeting of the Quarantine was held yesterday under the presidency of Dr. .Buffer. Four new members were elected 4 to the Permanent Commiasion, and the qnes tion of the importation of cattle from Servia received considerable attention. Dr. Ruffer ' and Mr. de Courcy have left for Tor.

div.head: Crime in the Provinoes
div.p: Fang Hendaoui, a nativo of tho village' of Nahir el-Massourea, was endeavouring to light u fire oh his roof, when an Albanian guard in the service of Prinoe Kamel-el-Dine became so enraged at the native's refusal to put out the . fire that he drew hw revolver and shot him dead. The murderer was immediately arrested.

div.head: Murder of an Omdeh.
div.p: Omar Abit, Omdeli of the village ofTouh, was killed while inspecting his property. A shot was fired by a unknown person concealed among the cotton bushes. The servants of the Omdeli hurried to the spot on hearing the report of tl|e gun, only to find their master dead. The police consider it an act of ven- geance.

div.head: Theatre des Ambassadeurs
div.p: A gala performance will be given this evening at title Théâtre des Ambassadeurs on the occasion of the début of "La Belle Andalouse," who is the leading dancer of the Theatre Royal at Madrid. The per- formance is timed to start at 9:30 and a complete change of programme and reduc- tion in prioes of admission has been made.

div.head: Police Libel Case
div.p: The action brought by tho Mamour of Karmouz district against the three Arabic organs "Al Mokattam", "Al-Watan," and "Al Shark," came before the Cairo Summary Tribunal thin morning. Hopkinson Bey has gone to Cairo to give evidence, and Mustapha Bey Fahmy lias been elected president of the court Attia Bey Hussein conducted (be prosecution. The damages claimed are $3,000.

div.head: Tram Accidents
div.p: Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clnok, while attempting to mount a tram in Sharia Clot Bey, Dr. Moliamed Efl. Nached was run into by Another tram coming from Rod el Fang and received such injuries to both legathat two month's treatment in hospital will be necessary. A native woman, named Farida, was also knocked down by a tram at Shoubra and very severely injured, hav- ing three ribs broken. Procès-verbaux have been drawn up against the wattmans.

div.head: Plague
div.p: During the w*ek ending the 5tii instant, 15 cases of plague were reoorded through- out Egypt, of which 18 were reported from Alexandria, 1 at Dainanbour, atid 1 at Minieh. From the beginning of the year up to tbe 5th August, 1043 cases of bubonic plague were registered, as against 404 reoorded during the corresponding period of last year. I admission to, 1 death outside and 9 deaths ih hospital at Aleiandria were the only ca- ses registered daring the past 24 hoora. 14 patients still remain under treatment.

div.head: THE YEMEN TROUBLE
div.p: TURKISH TROOPS AT HODEIDA
ACTIVITY OF THE REBELS
(From our owwn correspondent)

Aden, July 29. Advioes from Hodeida state that a batch of about 1,500 Turkish tira ^expired troops have arrived there from Sana and other places for embarkation to their homes. They waited there for some days hut no transport steamer was provided lor them. As uajial these dis- contented soldier Have grown weary and are giving greAt .trouble to the people At Hodeida. They looted the shops and houses of the natives, and had a fight with the latter, in which about 80 casualties have occurred. The natives have been closing their shops tor several day*.- A few days previous to this, another batch of Turkish time-expired troops proceeded to Hodeida for embarkation, and similarly looted the goods of the natives, and several casualties occurred, and when they: embarked they had a fight amongst themselves on board the ship It seems inexplicable why snch desperate troops should be let loose upon the natives before a transport ship is arranged for, and there is no reason why a steamer should not be chartered or a transport-ship brooght to be ready for the day of the troops arrival, for such occurrences are having disastrous morel effect News has reached Hodeida from Constanti- nople regarding the appointment of General Raggeb Pasha as Military Commander in Yemen, but the appointment, lias not yet been officially announced. It is reported that some Bedouins from the interior of Hodoida attacked a house in Hodeida, and killed one of the inmates of the house and plundered the property. Aden, August 1. Advises from Yemen state that the rebels have occupied several place# and strong posi- tions lying botweeu Hodeida and Sana. One oi these places is Mullian, a strong position about 2 days'journey northeast of Hodeida, and not garrisonod but is rulod . by a Sheikh. It was taken without resistance by the inhabitants. Another place captured by the rebels is Hatasli which liés about the same distance from Hodeida as Mullian. It is divided from Mulhan by a valley, and is not garrisoned by Turkish troops. It was also taken with- out fighting. Tbe rebels 'attackod Al Muhwait, a Turkish coffee-growing centre lying about 3 days' journey from Hodeida. This district is in- habited by a comparatively industrious peoplo. The rebels plundered the inhabitants and captured a number of them and conveyed them to the Inlaln. A desperate body of the rebels under Ibn Hoobaisb, who comes from tiro district of Al Muhwait, and who has rooently joined tlie standard of tho Imam, attacked Beni Kais, a district abont one day's journey North-East of Hodoida, and ruled by an Arab, Abdulla Pasha Al Boaui, who is under the protection of the Turks. The rebels had an engagement with Al Boaui, in which the latter last about 40. Anis, a Turkish district lyving about two days' journey from Sana and not garrisoned by Turkish troops, has been captured by the rebels without resistance from the inhabitants. Later advices from Hodeida state that the Turkish time expired troops hail another fight witti tho natives, in which about six casualties of the former, and about five of the latter have occurred. .

div.head: WEATHER OF JULY
div.p: The following report on the weather of last molith has been issued by the Survey Depart- ment:- As is usually the case at this time of the year, there has lieen but little variation from day to day in the weather. Normal conditions haVe been maintained over the Eastern Mediter- ranean, there being a steady gradient towards the East over tho sea and over Egypt. In the Sudan, tliosnmmor depression which isprobably connected with that of Northwestern India in the monsoon seasoir, has been fully developed in the neighbourhood of Suakin, causing the usual southerly and southwesterly winds in the Sudan. Atmospheric pressure was above normal in Egypt but slightly below in the Sudan. Mean temperature was slightly below the normal value everywliere exoept at Merowe and El Obeid. . The rains, which bod been weak in June, shewed but little improvement in July, and, except at a few stations, the total fall was considerably below the average. Ort the whole, this deficiency on the Abysaininn tableland seems to have amounted to about 38 per cent, but during the lost fow days there has been an improvement which is reported to extend to the Arabian Sea and Northwest India.

div.head: DREDGERS FOR SHANGHAI
div.p: (From Our Own Correspondent)

SUEZ, Tuesday. Yesterday forenoon two huge Dutch dred- gers the "Colonnia" and "Schelde," came ont of the Canal towed by the tugs "Thames" and "Rbenia." .These dredgen are bound to Shanghai, but owing to one of the tngs having broken 8 blades of her propeller in the Canal, their departure lias been postponed till repairs are completed.

div.head: THE BANDMAN FOLLIES
div.p: AN EXCELLENT COMBINATION

Cairo, Monday. It is seldon, indeed, that members of the British community in Cairo meet in snch large numbers, as was they case to-night in the Abbas Theatre on the ^occasion. of the first performance of Mr. Bandmann's new troupe 'The Follies," and the extent of theattonr dauoe was as surprising to tha audience itself, unhappily accustomed to half empty theatres, as the packed hoase mast have been gratifying to the aetore and astsmees.-From an early hour on Monday evening the doors of the theatre were eagerly besieged by a crowd, who it was evident had omitted to reserve their seats beforehand, and shortly before the curtain was timed to rise an altogether exceptionally influx of people blocked the gangways. Fortu- nately the building is a large one gad everyone eventually succeeded ip finding a place. In short, the attendance was excellent- amMpost nmque for a summer entertainment of this kind. . * The words of the opening chorus oonveyed a lucid description of the artists' powers, which afterwards were proved to be in no way ex- aggerated, but the musical rendering offered small promise of the excellent programme, which was in reality to follow. A certain amonnt of hesitation was noticeahle, nniaon was poor and the general idea given was that rehearsals had been neglected. It ig a pity that the very first item should havo beon so weak, especially as one is inclined to form opinions,' however erroneous, from the opening turns. Fortunately, however, this was the only disap- pointing part of a lengthy and really excelleat entertainment. Mr. Villiers Arnold, who is a powerful bnritone, gave 'Take a Pair .of S|iarkling Eyes" in an exceedingly pleasing way and there is no donbt that the applause, with which the song was received, was thoroughly earned. In the second part of the programme his song "Tho Mediterranean" was delivered with even more swing, and Mr.. Arnold is to bo congratulated upon having an exceptionally melodious voice, which is at the same time clear and strong. Miss Emilia Tait.waf the next to give us a talented exhibition of her powers, and, though her roioe is, perhaps,* trifle small for so large abuilding as tho Abbas Theatre, still the purity of her notes and the sweetness of tone was remarkable, and her encore, "The- Pomeranian Dog," is catchy and waf).enthu- siastically applauded. Spaco does not allow of a very full account of the entertainment and several clever turns must neoosaarily be over- looked, but mention must be made of Mr. H. Herbert, who is the life and soul of tlie'tronpe, and who kept tho house in roars of laughter for many minutes with his witty songs and his killingly funny facial contortions. Neither must Mr. Osborne's ventriloqnial sketch be passed over wi thou t special comment. The dexterity with which he modified and diminished the sonnd of the voice and carried the art of illusion to the height of perfection, entitles him to be called a prince of ventriloquists. Again, the accompan- ist, Mr. G. Stamford, proved himself worthy of attention, despite the fact that in his piano solo he scarcely succeeded in altogether master- ing the difficulties of an intricate piece, for he humourously illustrated to ns how musio may be safely pirated and cleverly manipulated so as to form an original operetta. Miss Florence Beech is a charming and most talented actress, who soon gained the sympathy of the audience by. her pretty face and graoeful movements. One noticeable fact of the evening was that the encores were invariably superior to the advertised tarn. The musical portion of the programma was followed by a new series of pictures on the London Bioscope which were extremely-interesting, although at times some- what indistinct The entertainment is a very enjoyable one, the jokos are fresh and entirely free from any double meaning, a bet which is rare indeed in this country, and, iii short, the entire per- formance is of a high order and is perhaps best described by a remark overheard in the vestibule "It is a white man's show". The standard of excellency attained from a musical point of view is so good that many of Monday night's audience intend to be présentât all the 'subsequent performances, which will be chang- ed each night Cairo, Tuesday, 'The Follies" gave another most excellent performance at the Abbas Theatre last night, on the occasion of their second appearance, before an even more enthusiastic audience than that which assisted at the opening entertain-, ment. The programme, which waa entirely changed, was, porhaj*, superior to the previous night and the artists, who appeared to have somewhat recovered from the fatigues of their recent travels, Were in first rate form and are to be heartily tluniked for having furnished us with a really most enjoyable evening. Mis* Emilie Tait was again greatly applauded, as was also the pianist Mr. Stamford, who de- monstrated his peifect mastery over the keys in a most humourous and interesting manner. Encores were frequent and judging froip last night's reception the troupe ought to leave our shores well pleased with the welcome which Egypt has accorded them.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Moss liner "Memepthah" sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is now due here on Saturday with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The S.S "Scottish Prince", with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 1st inst, and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 17th inst.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL ADVISERSHIP
div.p: SIR.V.CORBETT'S SUCCESSOR

Speculating as to the probable soocsseore to Sir Viooent Corbett, "Al Watan" Bays It appears that a vast minority of the Nation- alist papers prefer the appointment of Chitty Bey to the post when the present Adviser re- tires, presumably because that honest and experienced gentleman was known to favour the employment and promotion of Individuals of the predominant partner. He is one of the ver^faw $igli*hmen who are mentioned by the Nationalist papers without acerbity or acrimony. We congratulate Chitty Bey upon this distinction and are with the corres- pondent of the "Bgyptian Gazette" who thinks that he has the best claim for the high po- sition, by virtue of bis former servioes in the fliianci*] departments of the Egyptian Go- vernment But it would be the height of folly to prophecy that Chitty Bey is the next Financial Adviser, as the functions of the- post are more diplomatic than financial nwr* that the finances of the oountry are in the best condition, and that no schemes or special measures are required for meeting defieite or raising new funds. We want all Baring or Goacben now at the Ministry of Finance, (hanks to the former workers who have brought our finances to the present state of efficiency almost amounting to perfection. We want a diplomat and a statmesman in the post which is the official link between England and Egypt. The Financial Adviser is practically the deputy and representative of the British Agency before the Egyptian Ministry. He is even numbered among our Ministers, for he is called to meetind and allowe to vote on all questions with them, his vote being considered the wish and he policy of the ruling power. HE is at times the British Agency and the Egyptian Government combined inasmuch as he over rules the action of our Cabinet in the name of the British Government.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: The Council of Ministers decided at yester- day's meeting to grant the rank ofMoutamaix of the second class to Hussein "Bey Magdi, ea pension, and the second rank to Ibrahim Zeki Bey, and , Ahmed Khairy Bey; and approved of the appointment of Mr. Alexander Orla rôvsky as Russian Commissioner of the Public Debt. They also sanctioned the opening a credit of £10,000.for the Ministry of Interior for the bubonic and bovine plague measures and tbe establishment of new cemeteries in Menoufieh, Dakahlieh, and Minieh provinces.

div.head: NORWEGIAN STEAMER AGROUND.
div.p: (From our own Correspondent)

Suez, Tuesday. The Norwegian steamer "Him," bound to Shanghai from Antwerp, is badly aground in the Galf of Suez, North of Ras Garib light- house. This morning a tug with lighters and labour left Suet to go to her assistance

div.head: THE VITRIOL CASE.
div.p: The Belgian Consular Tribunal met yester- day at 6 p.m., under the presidency of the Consul M. Eid assisted by MM. Merzbach and Naus, in order to inquire into the charge against Vittorine Heureux. The evidence of the various witnesses was taken, the most impor- tant of which was given by M. Nadel, who gave first aid to the victim, and who heard Vittorine Heureux, cry "He has had what be deserves." Captain Renda mid the excited state of the prisoner at the time of arrest, confirmed her words "I am the avenger." Mme Omad at whose house Heurewx lodged aud worked, said that the prisoner had de- clared that she had a child whose father was not M. Goldsmith. On the day of the crime she waa extremely nervoos, and after visiting her son in the hospital had retnmed in tears, and later on went out, murmuring words of venge- ance. She returned at 9 p.m.and wan incoherent in her sleep. The accused said tliat the chemist at Shoubrah had refused to sell her the vitriol, and that at length she had stolen some. She affirmed her desire for vengeance and contend ed that her lover had beaten her. Counsel for.the defenoe, M. Eddé, has demanded an inquiry into the mental state of ML Goldsmith. The Tribunal will meet 'again on Saturday at 4 p.m.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Noua sommes heureux d'annoncer que sa- medi soir le 10 aura lieu le grand bal avec "Cotillon", que la direction du Casino offre à ses nombreux abonnés du Club et du Casino. Comme tontes les précédentes, cette fête promet d'être des plus réussies. Les abonnés n'ayant pas enoore reçu leur carte d'invitation, sont priés de bien vouloir la réclame* au secré- tariat du Casino. Jeudi après-midi nous aurons le plaisir d'en- tendre un programme tout-ft-fait nouveau, tut poar la partie vocale que pour l'instrumen- tale. Nous en publierons le détail demain.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: CRICKET
SHIPPING v. BANKS

Great interest .was taken yesterday by the members of the shipping firms and bub Of Alexandria, in the cricket match played on the Alexandria cricket ground between teams re- presenting the respective parties, and the pavilion was well orowded with enthusiastic spectator". The match commenced at 2.80 p.m, \nd the toss being won by Sampson the Banks took first knock. Birch and Inglott went to the wioket first, but Inglott, who played vary norvously, soon had his leg stomp dispUomi by McLean. Inglott shaped well and looked liked getting set, but after three oven he drove a tempter right back to Hobbainn, who was bowling well on the wicket Reid bade Very short stay with no reSalt, ud Roll immediate- ly afterwards fell a victim to a leg yorker from McLean. Cull, who followed. Reid, played very steady ud cautions cricket, letting .off muy balls which should have hem, punished, bet in the long run he ud Sampson r|Al their aide from an ignominious defeat Th^Bfiters of the opening were unchecked until u^nintb wioket had fallen, Richards being run ont and Merton, Lucke, Barrow, ud Martin falling victims to McLean in quick succession. MoLean was bowling splendidly and performed the hat trick with the 7th, .8th, and 9th wickets. Whan Sampnon joined Col), however, a different oom- plexion was pot on the game. Nine wickets had fallen for 99 runs but both plaÿen, though taking no advantages, got the mastery over the ball,- and brought the total up to 112 before Sampson's off stump was displaced by Wellinga. Cull's 56 not out was undoubtedly the feature the iuning* ud included 12 boundaries. oLean took 6 rrioketa for 80 runs, ud Hobsbaum 2 for 12,-ftnd though Spurgeon took no wickets as a change bowler he kept * good length and kept runs down, but Riohlay's three overs proved very expensive. The Shipping team opened very well. Per- kins and Harkness immediately got to work, the latterly driving the hall to. the boundary frequently, while the former, playing, qni*$hr, made single after single. Both players made the bowling look very simple and 46 was registered before Harkness drove his ball into Birch's hud. Moss then' f*rt- nered Perkins ud immediately took lib- erties with 'tlio bowling, the neoend ball which he received being driven straight to the off boundary. With the score at 66 Perkins was out l.b.w. o to Sampson, but Wallace, who followed, oontinuad to keep things merry with Mom until the latter's middle stump was displaced by Sampson with the total at 77. Mclean only stopped for one lusty drive to the on boundary ud then Wellings kept his end up while Wal- laoe knocked the ball about. The 61h jickatput ^!n on 27 bnt the next only addsd three, for Merton was pet oa to bowl underfund lobs ud immediately caused a rot, taking 5 wick- ets for 3 runs, Sampson took 4 wickets for 86 runs. Birch 1 for 38, and Roll 0 for 37. In their second innings the Buks fared very badly, McLean proving deadly. Two wioket* fell before a ran had been scored, Birch's middle stump being knocked out of the ground by McLean's first delivery, and the wickets fell in quick snccessioa Stumps were drawn at half past six with nine wiokets down ud only 43 runs on the board. McLean came out the with splendid analysts of 7 overs, 8 maidens, 9 runs, 8 wickets, and Wellings took 1 wicket for 10 runs. Mr. H. Moss was "at home" during the afternoon, tea ud light refreshments were served, and the match was greatly enjoytd by both players ud spectators.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché a ouvert ee matin forme et anuné. Toute I* ftéanoo a d'ailleure été remarquable ment tenue, excepté ven la fia oh une légère réeotion s'est produite à la suite d'offres de vente provenant du Claire. En définitive l'en- semble de la oote eet en hausse comme hier, mais oomme hier aussi les affaires n'ont pas été nombreuses. Il n'jr a pas de vendeurs et l'on oomprend que dans de telles circonstances les acheteurs ont beau jeu pour pousser les cours à peu de frais. . En valeur* dirigeantes lé calme prédomine. A part l'AgriooIe quia donné lieu k quelques transactions, les autresn'ont guère étééchangée. - L'Agricole s'avance de 8 1/16 à 8 1/8 ven- deurs, la National Bank de 19 7/8 à 20, tandis que la Daïra eet plus faible à 18 7/8 vendeurs et que la Delta Light revient de 9 15/16 à 9 7/8 et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 304 à 303 l'ancienne et de 269 à. 261 vendeurs la nouvelle. L'Agrioole et la National Bank, d'a- bord l'objet d'une demande suivie du Caire, ont été ensuite offertes en clôture. On a beaucoup remarqué des achats en Land Bank dont le oours progresse de ce fait de 7 3/16 à 7 1/4. lia demande provient de Paris. 1a demande en Tramways d'Alexandrie, particulièrement en Dividendes, a occasionné une nouvelle reprise sur les oours qui s'avan- cent de 139 1/2 & 142 1/2 les Privilégiées et de 292 k 300 les Dividendes. Cette recherche par les marchés étrangers de certaines de nos valeurs entre évidemment en ligne de compte pour l'amélioration oons- taote de notre place depuis une quinzaine de jours. D'antres valeurs profitent du mouvement: la Cassa di Soon to bénéficie de 6 fr. à 38, la Banque d'Athènes de 1 fr. jt 111 1/2, la Deferred Delta de 1/4 de livre à 9 1/2, ainsi que les Nangovioh à 13 1/4, le Comptoir de 3/16 l'action à 2 13/16 l'ancienne et 2 3/4 la nouvelle et de 1/4 de livre la part de fonda- teur & 3, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 1/16 à 4 1/8, la Banque d'Orient de 4 fr. à-118 1/2. L'Alexandria Water fléchit, au contraire, de 11.1/8 à 11 7/16, et l'Urbaine de 8 11/16 à 8 6,8. Parmi les petites valeurs, la Sait and Soda S'élève de 17/8 k 17/9,-les Rito de 11/16 à 8/4, la Delta Irend de 1 8/4 à 1 18/16, et 'a fonda- teur Allotment de 70 k AO P.T., tandis que les Ootton Mills faiblissent de 2/6 k 2/, les 8ucreries de 86 à 80, et l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail de 22 à 21/9. ' Suris reste de la cote il n'y a pas de chan gements k signaler. On dit qu'une asset importante maison de courtage et reports du Caire serait sur le point de déposer son bilan. Une maison de oourtage d'Alexandrie est également aux prises avec de sérieuses difficultés. C'est domain que doit avoir lieu le règle- ment des transactions en Bourse and Banking. On est généralement d'avis que les prihcipaux intéressés dans l'affaire n'ayant pas donné leur consentement à la décision de l'association, le règlement n'aura pas lieu. On se trouvera dans ce cas an même point oh l'on en était avant la décision.

div.head: Circulaire H. Des Virs et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Ckire, Mardi 6 Août Le taux de l'eaeompte libre k Londres se maintient inchangé k 3 8/4 pour cent Le Stock Exchange était fermé samedi et lundi à l'oocasion du Bank Holiday. A Parjp, le-Crédit Foncier Egyptien a baissé hier de 4 franca à 682. IA Banque d'Athènes s'eet relevée de 1 franc à 113. Les Lots Turcs ont gagné 2 francs à 169. # a o o . loi, les quelques jours de repos que viept de prendre notre marché lui ont profité, car l'animatioo déjà fort réjouiseante la semaine dernière, a continué aujourd'hui de plus belle ; aussi la cote présentent elle une hausse quasi générale sur les valeurs traitées. La oonfiancc un moment ébranlée, parait actuellement tout à fait revenue et l'activité se porte de préfé- rence sur les valeurs locales foncières et immo- bilières. Les titras des grandee Banques qui, il y a quelques semaines encore, avaient seuls un marché suivi, bien qu'améliorant encore leur position, restent un peu dans l'ombre au profit de valeurs moins lourdes et susceptibles do plus-values considérables eu égard à leur bas prix. La projet de rétablissement du marché à tenue a exercé aussi une très heureuse influence en ee sens qu'on en attend de bons résultats en faveur de la reprise. ^ Dans le compartiment dot Banques, l'Agri- cole reste forme à 8 1/16. La National Bank hanmede l/"à20. Le Crédit Foncier ae maintient sans affaires k 687 francs. Les obligations anciennes recu- lent à 302. L'Allotment réagit légèrement k 2 1/4-5/14 et la fondateur avance à P T. 60. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux coati- nueot à être très demandées à 1 Ift/16 en gain de 8/14. LA Héliopolia aooentoent leur avance i 947 et leur part à 11 1/2. Dana le groupa dos Hôtels, les Egyptian HMols(Bashler) haussent de 3/16 à 56/16. Lee Nangovioh sa referent à 18 8/8 et les Bits finissent fi 0 t/kT Planai les petites valeur", U Delta Land resta favorisée à I 8/4-18/16. Les Estates se ooMoiidaat àO 11/16 et leur part à 4 3/8. Lee Nev-Egyptian remontent h 14/9 et les Egyp^ " |à 0 7/16. Las Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie étant fermées hier par suite du chômage des mar- chés anglais" notre Circulaire n'a pat paru ainsi qu'à l'ordinaire. o o Plusieurs de nos leoteurs européens nous ayant demandé si les rentes faillites surve- nues en Egypte avaient réellement atteint le chiffre de trois millions de livres sterling, oomme oortaina organes de Paris l'ont annoncé, noua saisissons l'oocasion de remettre les choses au point. Ainsi qoe la reprise des valeurs égyptienne" à Londres et fi Paris l'a montré, reprise suivie de stabilité, le marché égyptien n'a jamais été aussi atteint que des correspondante effrayés ont bien voulu /'écrire en Europe. La vérité se résume en offque la orise égyptienne a été pro- voquée par un resserrement. de OTédit qni a forcé quelques spéculateurs fi réaliser leur por- tefeuille. Il s'en est suivi de nouvelles baisses qui ont obligé les détenteurs de titras, trop foibles pour les soutenir, fi les vendre. Cela, et la pénurie monétaire régnante ont amené ia gène dont l'Egypte est actuellement en voie de se libérer. Quant aux défaillances autour desquelles ont a mené grand bruit, elles n'ont en que très peu d'influenoe sur le marché boursier. Elles ont été uniquement provoquées par le brusque retrait des crédits que les banqueseuropéennos avaient toujours consenties fi quelques ban- ques privées do la place. Au demeurent, d'ailleurs, les maisons visées ont toutes pu s'arranger avec leurs créanciers d'antant plus facilement que leur actif dépas- sait fortement leur passif, qui est en somme peu important Actuellement la situation est redevenue normale et les banques égyptiennes possèdent des quantités considérables de numéraire, de façon fi répondre facilement aux besoins d'ar- gent que fera naître la prochaine campagne cotonnière. * " o Cet après-midi aura lieu une assemblée de la Corporation des agents de cliange aux fins d'examiner la question du marché fi terme et délibérer sur les mesures fi prendre on vue do son rétablissement II est pins que probablo qu'une très forte majorité se prononoera pour l'affirmative. o o Carnet de l'actionnaire. Les actionnaires de la Banque d'Escompto et de Reports d'Egypte ot du Soudan Ltd sont informés que le quatrième etdernier versement sor les actions de oet te Société devra être ef- fectué an plus tard le 24 Août prochain au si*ge social au Caire et à 1A Banque d'Orient fi Alexandrie. " o Une assemblée générale extraordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Cy Ltd. est convoquée pour le mardi 13 Août oourant fi ■ 6 heures p.m. au siège de la Société au Caire. A l'ordre du jour : Modifications fi apporter fi l'art. 87 des statuts

div.head: TELEGRAMS
div.p: THE CASA BLANCA TROUBLE
FRENCH TROOPS LAND
ATTACKED BY MOORS

CASABLANCA, August 6. Tl"o commander of the "Galilée" demanded mid obtained permission to disembark troops to guard tjie Frenoh Consulate. On landing a nnmlicr of Moors attacked the troops, wound- ing seven. The French then charged with tlio bayonet killing a number of the Moors. At the same time the "Galilé" and "Du Cliaÿla" bombarded the town, their fire being, most efficacious. Sorao Spaniards took part in the combat. The French occupy the town. o (Hal'as) , 'PARIS, August 6. General Drude will command the French troops at Casablanca. (Reuter) TANOTF", August 6. The French and Spanish men-of-war have arrived and landed a force which was attacked by the Kabyles. Six Frenchmen and one officer have been wounded. After posting guards at the Consulates the ''Galilée'' bombarded the Moorish quarter and surrounding districts. It is believed that 150 Moors have been killed by the bombardment. (Reuter)

div.head: ROYALTY ON "DREADNOUGHT"
div.p: EXCELLENT SHOOTING PRACTICE

LONDON, August 6. The King and Queen, the Prince and Prin- cess of 'Wnlos, and the Duke of Connaught took " trip to sea on board tho "Dreadnought" They witnessed the practice with the 12inch guns. Out of 12 shots in three minutes 11 hits were made, 9 of which wore ''bulls," at a range of U milles : the target was 18 feet square. They afterwards witnessed submarine maneuvuers Above and below tho furface. (Reuter)

div.head: THE SWINEMUNDE MEETING.
div.p: PEACE OF THE WORLD.

LONDON, August G. Semi-official statements from Berlin and Stj Petersburg declare that the discussions at Swinemunde covered all the questions of the moment and testified to the desire of both Powers- to preserve the peace of world. They have in nowise modified existing alliances, while strengthening Russo-Gcrmnn friendship. Confidence is expressed that Franco-Spnnish notion in Morocco; in consequonoo of recent events, will lead, to no complications. They further state that it- is recognised that Russo- Japanese convention and the prospective Anglodtussian agreement was most conducive to the maintenance of general peace. div.head: SARAPION OF THUMUIS AND HIS PRAYER BOOK
div.p: BY JOSEPH OFFORD

A few years ago an ancient docuuiont of first rajeimportanoe for the history of Christian- ity in Egypt was disoovered, and reoeivod far less notice than it deserved.. This was the "Prayer Book of Bishop Sarapion" which may be termed an Egyptian Pontifical dating from the fourth century. The author is a well known personage, for this "Sarapion was Bishop of Thmuis, a.oity of Lower Egypt, in the Delta near Lake Monzaleb. The site of its ruins is now known ns Tmey-el-Amdid, about five miles east of the railway between Mansura and Abu Kebir. The town was not far from Meades, the chief scat, of the goat god of the old Egyptians, Snd the name Thmuis is thought to have been derived from Thmu, the male goat.* This Sarapion was a valued friend of two.pre- eminent Egyptian Ecclesiastics, ; Athanasius and Anton}', the latter of whom bequeathed a cloak to Sarapiou on his death bed. The recovery of this manuscript containing the lost work of Sarapion was not so much noticed in Egypt because it was not found there but in a monastery in Greece. The date of the writing of the treatise is somewhere between AJ). 350 and 858. It is not the only book we possess by its author, there being extant a treatise by him against the Manioheans, and several epistles. He was, however, chiefly famous as being the recipient of five very valuable letters, from a theological point of view, addressed to him by Athanasius. The number of prayers in this series by Sarapion is thirty, and they are not intended, apparently, for use by the laity or congregation hut by the minister. A aurions occurrence in them is to be found in the appli- cation of -a number of titles to the Divinity which appear to be founded upon similar con- cepts to those which are embodied in the eulogistic names given to the Ptolenmio mon- nrohs, such as filantropos ; JHoptocos ; ererghe- tie ; anil filantropia. One of tho Sarapion prayers is a petition for rain, and a similar one in to be found in the old Coptic Jacobite Church service. Thmuis, being in tho Delta, lay within the region of the rains which there, in winter, are borne over the land by the northern wind off the Mediter- ranean, the mean rainfall at Alexandria being about eight inches. This is not the place to enter into any discussion of tho theological tenets of the treatise, but one or two points of general interest may be referred to. For in- stance in Dr. G. Wordsworth's edition of Sara- pion he points out that the well known phrase as to renouncing Satan and his ''pomps'' and vanities originated in the phrase of the very early renunciation which was repeated by con- verts, and which is first recorded in the "Canons of Hippolytus," in which they promised to renounce Satan and his "pompa" or followers (cortogo). Mr. Salomon Rciuach detected this fact about the same time as Dr. Wordsworth in reference to a passage in Tertullian, giving the correct meaning of "pompa." Among tho ecclesiastics who appear in the hierarchy in this mnnuscript are "Interpreters", a necessary .class of persons to render any Greek pronouncements into Coptic or vice versa. In a very early account of a visit to the Holy Land known as the "Perigrinatio Silvia" it is said- that at Jerusalem the Interpreter always stood by the Bishop to interpret his allocations into Syriac, and at least one eminent Syriac ecclesiastic is known as "Theo- dore the Interpreter." To anyone olosoly acquainted with ancient Egyptian literature tho 18th prayer has a very Egyptian character about it. It is termed "Prayer for ono who is dead and about to be carried forth" ; it alludes to God as the "God of the spirits", also to the Gates of Hades in tlje plural, reminding ono of the old Egyptian "Book of Gates" or "Book of Pylons" in the nether world. It also promises a resting place to the spirit "in green places" and' in chambers, very similar to tlio formulae of tho "Book of the Ani-Tuat" and especially alludes to the "going forth of the soul", which is very liko the "going forth" or "coming forth" of tho "Book of the Dead." These may be mere coincidences, hut tho certainty of the derivation from old Egyptian sources of much of the description of the inferno in the recently-found "Apocalypse of Peter" renders it probable that wc liavo hero from Sarapion ideas which were originally in the ancient Egyptian theology.

div.head: THE YEMEN TROUBLE
div.p: The special oonwpcmdflit of the "Times" it Bey rout sends an important message, dated July, 11th., to that journal describing the pre- sent serious condition of affairs in the Yemen, of the increasing difficulties Vhioh the Turkish Coinnrtander has to face. } That the military situation in Yemen is un- satisfactory appears clearly ho says, by tiie fact that tho most optimistic letters which have reached Damascus from the front during the past wook merely express the belief thntFaixi Pasha and his force will be able to bold Sanaa till the arrival of tho reinforcements which were so insistently demanded by the oom- mander of the Yemen Field Force The idea that the appearance of these reinfor- cements on the scene of aotion can haVe any permanent effect on the issue of the campaign is scouted in Syria, where it is believed that the Imam Yshya will, at most retire before the new forces into the mountains and thence oondnot a ha- ing guerilla campaign till the inevitable wastage of the Turkish armies enables him to take the field with a better chance of success Moreover, it iB improbable that the Tnrjdsh forces, as at present organised and equipped, can ever force their more mobile opponents to action in the open, while the'rebels in their own mountains are now considered to be tactically equal, if not superior, to the Turks. The utter inefficiency of the coast blockade, or rather watch, conduotod by a few superan- nuated gunboats and Customs craft enables tlio contraband trade in arms and ammuni- tion between Yemen and Massawah, Jibuti, and other ports on the west ooast of the Rod Sea to be carried on with the minimum of risk. Many thousand rifles and large quantities qf ammunition have been captured during tho oampnign, and tho shoot- ing of the insurgents .is said to be far more accnmte than that of the majority of the Turkish troops, whose musketry train- ing, ns a rule, begins and ends with man- ual exercises in the liandling of an empty rifle. Tho deficiency in the ammunition snpply, which hnH caused Faizi Pasha great anxiety, is now being remedied by large indents on the rosorvo ammunition of the First (Constantino- ple) and second (Adrianople) Army Corps, bnt the disorganization of the transport, the utter breakdown of the under staffed and ill-equipped medical .service, and the indif- ferent inoral both of officers and men mili- tate far more seriously against Faizi Pasha's chances than tho notorious weakness of his troops in tactics and musketry. There are still numerous Syrian Moslems among the troops in Yemen, whose presence constitu- tes an olement of woakuess, though the Syrian soldiers showed remarkable powers of endurance during the siege of Sanaa in 1905. They are accused by the Turkish oftioors of sympathizing with and even of giving information to the rebels, and these accusations would seem to be well-fonnded as fpr the last hîx months scarcely any Syrian reservists or recruits have been called to the colours for service in Yemen. Outbreaks among the troops on the transporte bound to and from Hodeida are becoming a regular feature of the journeys of these overcrowded and insani- tary vessels. Thus, on July 4, the transport Marmara arrived here from Hodeida with 2,800 time-expired Syrian and Turkish soldiers on board. On the arrival of tho transport Rear- Admiral Fayek Pasha ordered her captain to remain outside the harbour and to inform the troops that their arrears of jury, amounting to £T82,000, would be paid very shortly, and tliat they must, therefore, make no demonstra- tion. Tho troops, however, insisted on the Marmara being brought into port, and on the following day landed en masse and made a noisy demonstration before the Defterdar'a house, with the result that the arrears due to them werq- paid, £T25,000 in cash and the balanoe.in "sanads" (orders on the provincial treasuries for the remission of taxes). Still more serious is the attitude of many of the officors at the front. Several very discreditable surrenders have taken place, and-there is no doubt that a number of the officers of tho Sanaa garrison mutinied early in June, seized tho telegraph offioe, and telegraphed their complaints to Constantinople, threatening to surrender or abandon their posts unless their grievances were speedily remedied. Indeed, it is difficult not to believe that the insurgents could have driven the Turkish forées to the ooast six months ago, but for the mutual su8pioions and jealousies of their lead ors, and it is'just this inability oq the part qf the A rabs, settled or nomad, to èombine aga- inst the unpopular rale of the Turk that has prevented any extension of tho rebellion beyond tho Yemen provinoe and the southern districts of Azir. The Hedjazis openly grumble at tho approach of the railway, which will shorten the Syrian pilgrimage and injure the hosts of camol owners, traders, and others, who batten on the much-enduring Hadji, but os yet show no signs of supporting the heretioal Zaidis_of Yemen, whose Imam has claimed equality with the Sherif of Meoca. In Nejd, the warfare of the kites and crows, Ibn Sand against Ibn Rashid, continues without decisive result Aided by a cousin and two brothers, Sul- tan Ibn Rashid in no wise departed from the tiédirions of his bouse when he trea- cherously slew his cousin the Emir Mut'ib and three of bis kinsmen^ some eight months ago. and proclaimed himself Emir of Hail. Abd el Aziz ibn Saud, Emir of Riadh, who had made truce with Mut'ib, forthwith vowed vengeance, and waged war in the desultory Bednin fashion against the usurper, defeated Sultan ibn Rashid's forces, and was himself surprised and all but captured in a, night attack which stampeded his undisciplined levies. The fears of a Wahabi attack expressed by the Turkish authorities at Medina have now been dissipat-ed. Brandu it* Rashid, trade of the osarping Sultan, a strong Wahabi, bos, doubtless with from the varions districts of NejdhaVe entered the holy city, thoir object has been to pay their respeots to an influential and religious chief who openly professes neutrality. Thus far, in the long straggle of the houses, fortune has, on the whole, favoured .the Beni Sand, but will this bo the oue when the Hqjaz railway has roaohed Medain Salih, and tin Turks, who have generally supported the Emir of Hail, are in a position to intervene effectively on bis behalf t The Yemen war may lost for years, but there seems to be little risk of any great combination of tire Arabs of Northern and Central Arabia against the steady southward advance of the Turk.

div.head: PALESTINE EXPLORATION FUND.
div.p: In the fourteenth quarterly report on the excavation of Gezer, Mr. Stewart Maoalia- ter, MA.,*F.8.A., says*- Early in November of last year I landed in Palestine, and almost immediately pro- ceeded to Constantinople to inquire into the progress of the negotiations Jor the new permit for the resumption of work at Geter. While in Constantinople, I had opportunities of attempting to extend an interest in the work of the Fund, by leoturing at Robert College, and at the Amerioan Collego for Girls at Soutari. I have to express my ac- knowledgments of tho friendly oourtesy with which their Excellencies Hamdy and Khalil Bey reoeived me in tho. magnificent museum under their control. I must also acknow- ledge the interest of the officials of his Majesty's Embassy, especially, Mr. Fitxmaur- ice, who was in chargo of the negotiations. Last, but not least, I hâve to render my oordial thanks to the Fund's stannch friend Mr. Edwin Pears, for much help and kindness. After finishing business in Constantinople I returned to Jerusalem, and a few days later set off for Safed-r-a diary of my visit there was contributed to the last Quarterly Statement. (1) Towards the end of February I heard that the permit was shortly to he issued. Soon after- wards it was actually in my hands. A week or two had to be spent in necessary preparations and certain official routine, bnt as soon as pos- sible I made my way to the mound. I am b*ppy report that I found it exactly as I left it, no barm having come to any qf .the buildings that were left open at the olose of the previous permit. This is to a large extent due to Mr. Murad's friendly care and interest. It is a matter for satisfaction that Surraya Efiendi Al-Khalidi, who during the previous peimit showed himself ready to further the interests of the Fund iu every way possible, consistently with a scropulous perfoimanoe of his own duties as Commissioner of the Otto- man Government, has been re-appointed to the same office. The actual work of excavation began March 18th, and, except for a couple of days at Easter, has been continued uninterruptedly. Tho weather lias been propitious, although hot south and east winds have been prevalent and on some days made exertion not a little labori ous. I have this time made a now departure, and built a lint to take the place of the tents in which the excavating party was formerly domiciled. On all grounds-comfort, eoonomy, stability, and security-the change has been found an improvement It may be remembered that just at the olose of the previous permit three remarkable tombe were found, which for Various reasons I sug gested might possibly be referable to the Phi listines. I hoped that these might prove to be the outlying tombs of a. cemetery, whioh, if it were actually Philistine, could not fail to afford results of the highest importance. The ground north, south and east of- these tombs was left uncut at the end of the permit I immediately commenced at this promising spot, and ran a trenoh north of the tombs to tho border of the mound : nothing, however, was fonnd in that direction. A pit was then dug to the south of these, and two more tombs of tho series wore there found. Excavations are now proceeding to the east, but at the moment of writing tho level of tho graves has not boen reached. - One pit has also boon dug on tho Eastern Hill. As nsua), in looking for oueHhing, another has been disoovered. The trenoh cut northward from tlie tombs was found to oontain an in- teresting foundation, apparently that of a Ca- aaanite palace or fortress. Beneath it was another of' tho very eerly caves which have been such a notable feature of tho mound of Gezer. The most interesting "find"-, from tho Eastern Hill has been a small stone altar. On the whole, however, the objects disoov- ered during the last two months have been of ah an average" character.

div.head: THE SOAP COMBINE.
div.p: A correspondent writes :- The outburst of joy evinced by the Euglish press at thé*awards in the libel actions'brought by Lever Brothers and Watson & Sons against the '*DaiIy Mail" is almost indecent in its unrestraint and passes the bounds of righteous indignation. Thé motive which induoed the chief pro prietor of the paper to undertake the cam- paign against the alleged soap trust last autumn is not easily explained. It was pro bably a mixed one. The various firms forming the soap coni bine wished to economise in their advertising departments which, through increasing com- petition, entailed an enormous expenditure. They also wished to be in a position to'pur- chase raw material more cheaply, and it is now alleged that fear of losing these v^l advertisements for the various publication! the Associated Press decided Lord Northoliffe in attacking the combine. It. is also stated that Lord Northcliffe combated the very methods in the soap combine which he lias personally introduced into journalism. He suoceeded in breaking the combine but in so doing he resorted to statements which were libellous and he has l>eeA called upon to pay the penalty, which is os it should be. No one however has given him credit for-a disinterest- ed motive, a desire to safeguard thepnblic 1 The "Daily Mail" has during its career, as its circulation will show, seriously affected tho sale of the morning papers sold at double the prioe and these papers naturally seize on this opportunity to discredit their rival befqra the: public. Therefore in' answer to their allegation' concerning the motives which inspired . laird Northoliffe in his campaign against the soap trust, one would ask "SinceVhen is Saul also among the prophets 1 The people who have the leisure in which to wade through a morning paper snoh as the "Times" or the ''Daily Telegraph" are in the minority and the "Daily Mail" supplied a long felt, want One need not nocéfi/arily assume-that people of intelligence form tlioi^' political views on the lines advocated by'that journal. . ti- Many ot those pre-eminent in the field of science and literature have contributed articles to the "Daily Mail" and,, while one regiets the strain of yellow journalism whioh, through it* news columns, it has introduced into England, one takes the perforvid outburst of Ita-rivals

div.head: NATIONALISTS
div.p: It is ho doubt fellow-feeling says the "Globe" which has made oertain of tb" Irish Nationalist politicians dispiny *o great aa interest in the movements of the Indian agitators. It is all one to them if they embar- rass tiie Government of the Empire in England or Asia, or, as they proved last year In discus- sing the Denshawi outrages, in Egypt, and a few years ago, in South Afriea. oomes to their mill. And similarly, it is not snrarising that the disloyal section of the Indian vernacular Press keeps itself and his readers well informed as to the program of the Sinn Fein League in Ireland, aid identifies the aims of the latter with the Swadeshi and the boycott in Bengal. Thé seditions have a keen eye for their fnénds all over the world, and they realise that an 'unacknowledged al- liance more than doubles their power. Bat the exposure of such tactics oughtto undeceive peine of those Radical sympathisera in this country as to the real character of the people with whom they are half-inclined to express sympathy. Unless they wish Ireland to be ruled by a tyrannical association of p$QQ who Use, a preposterous sham Gaelic propaganda to impotence has so often been proved through its subjugation by the wild tribe* of toe Himalayas, they will oease to give a passive support to sedition, from whatever quarter it may oomtL It Is one thing" to recogtnee legiti- mate grievances: it is very different wnen such grievances are manufactured for ulterior aims.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
